Introduction

Bacterial keratitis is a serious infection of the cornea most commonly caused by improper contact lens use and corneal injury (eg, abrasion).  Symptoms include severe eye pain, photophobia, mucopurulent discharge, and a foreign body sensation.  A round, white corneal infiltrate is the characteristic examination finding.  Patients require immediate ophthalmologic evaluation and broad-spectrum topical antibiotics to avoid vision-threatening complications (eg, corneal scarring, perforation).

Pathophysiology and risk factors



The cornea is the clear covering on the surface of the eye.  In addition to its role in light refraction, the cornea provides a structural barrier to protect the eye from infection.  The most common risk factors for infection of the cornea include:



  • Improper contact lens use (eg, extended wear/poor hygiene)
  • Corneal trauma (eg, abrasion):  disrupts the epithelium and allows bacterial entry
  • Ocular disease (eg, dry eye syndrome):  limits protective tear film


The most commonly isolated bacteria is Pseudomonas aeruginosa, especially in contact lens wearers.  Some cases are also due to Staphylococcus aureus infection, but these are much less common.

Clinical presentation



Common signs and symptoms of bacterial keratitis include:



  • Severe eye pain, foreign body sensation, and photophobia (typical of any corneal process)
  • Mucopurulent discharge
  • Blurred vision/decreased visual acuity


Examination findings include:



  • Corneal infiltrate (
    figure 1
    ):  a round, white lesion on the cornea that also stains with fluorescein (characteristic finding in bacterial keratitis)
  • Corneal opacity:  haziness/loss of transparency due to inflammatory cell infiltration
  • Scleral injection (ie, redness)
  • Hypopyon:  layering of white blood cells in the anterior chamber

Diagnosis



Bacterial keratitis should be considered in any patient with a red, painful eye, especially with contact lens use or recent trauma.  Diagnosis is confirmed by identifying a round, white infiltrate on the cornea.  Corneal cultures are not routinely obtained in mild keratitis (eg, small infiltrates), but microbiologic studies on corneal scrapings should be performed if the infection is severe.

Differential diagnosis



  • Herpes simplex keratitis (
    image 1
    ) causes symptoms similar to those of bacterial keratitis, but fluorescein examination reveals characteristic dendritic corneal lesions.
  • Fungal keratitis is rare and typically occurs in immunocompromised patients after corneal injury involving soil/plant matter.  Onset is gradual and corneal infiltrates have characteristic feathery margins.
  • Photokeratitis presents with bilateral eye pain, redness, and photophobia 6-12 hours after unprotected exposure to ultraviolet light (eg, welders).

Management



Bacterial keratitis is an ophthalmologic emergency; therefore, management includes rapid referral to ophthalmology for evaluation and immediate initiation of broad-spectrum topical antibiotics that cover against Pseudomonas (eg, fourth-generation fluoroquinolones).



Patients should be assessed daily for the first several days; improvement should be visible within a week.  The treatment course may last several weeks to months, depending on response.

Prognosis



Most cases improve within a week of initiating topical antibiotic treatment.  However, delayed or inadequate treatment can lead to complications, including corneal perforation, endophthalmitis (eg, infection of aqueous and vitreous humors), and corneal scarring; all can result in permanent vision loss.

Summary



Bacterial keratitis is a serious ocular infection involving the cornea that requires prompt recognition and management to prevent vision-threatening complications.  Improper contact lens use and corneal trauma are the leading risk factors.  Symptoms include eye pain, photophobia, mucopurulent discharge, and a foreign body sensation.  A white infiltrate on the cornea is a defining characteristic.  Treatment involves broad-spectrum topical antibiotics.
